09 Aug 2012

J & J Tells Me “You’re Ok Mom” and I Weep

By in category

It’s near impossible to relax when you’re under attack. But parents are facing just this challenge. This summer there have been a plethora of articles telling parents they need to ‘chill’ at the same time that they’re being told that, frankly, they are doing a shitty job. So shitty a job, in fact, that their kids are the most screwed up in generations.

The New Yorker started the ball rolling with asking “Why Are American Kids so Spoiled?” And the answer is:

“with the exception of the imperial offspring of the Ming dynasty and the dauphins of pre-Revolutionary France, contemporary American kids may represent the most indulged young people in the history of the world.”

The Globe and Mail has been wielding a similar sword, swinging like crazy at parents’ jugulars while again, telling them their far too uptight. The Globe asked Are Our Pampered Kids Under Too Much Pressure? and also offered advice about Why Parents Should Add “Relax” To Their To Do List.

In light on all this, this Johnson and Johnson ad is spot on. In classical advertising terms it exploits a truth. This truth has nothing to do with J & J’s products, but the fact that this little message is brought to you by a major corporation that sells toxic soap (among a litany of other horrors to mothers and babes) is of course more than a little sad.

It goes to show you the state of affairs for parents who are being consistently told they’re doing it all wrong. I can’t help crying every time I hear “you’re not perfect….but you’re trying.”  I’m glad someone, even an evil empire, is recognizing my parenting chops.
